sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2NO(g) + O2(g) ⟶ 2NO2(g) , given that the standard enthalpy of formation of NO(g), O2(g) and NO2(g) are 90.4 kJ/mol , 0 kJ/mol, and 33.2 kJ/mol, respectively?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

where ΔH°f represents the standard enthalpy of formation of each substance.

For the given reaction:

2NO(g) + O2(g) ⟶ 2NO2(g)

The standard enthalpy of formation for each substance is:

NO(g) = 90.4 kJ/mol
O2(g) = 0 kJ/mol
NO2(g) = 33.2 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 × 33.2 kJ/mol (NO2)] - [2 × 90.4 kJ/mol (NO) + 0 kJ/mol (O2)]

ΔH°(reaction) = (66.4 kJ/mol) - (180.8 kJ/mol)

ΔH°(reaction) = -114.4 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -114.4 kJ/mol.
